statements: For any $u, v, w \in V$, we have $x_{uv} + x_{uw} \ge x_{vw}$.
For every $uv \in E_H$, we have $(1 - \beta) \cdot d(v) \le d(u) \le \frac{1}{1-\beta} \cdot d(v)$.

Let $c \in \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0}^n$ be a vector and $\alpha > 0$ satisfying that $|c|_\infty \le \alpha$ and $|c|_1 \le \alpha k$. Then we have $\sum_{r \in V} c(r) \cdot \text{cost}_C(r) \le \alpha \cdot \text{cost}_C^k$.

There exists a vector $c_2^+ \in \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0}^n$ with the following properties:
(3.7a) $f_2^+ \le \sum_{r \in V} c_2^+(r) \cdot \text{cost}_C(r)$.
(3.7b) $c_2^+(r) \le \frac{2}{\beta} \cdot \frac{|\varphi_2^+(r)|}{d(r)}$, for every $r \in V$.
(3.7c) $|c_2^+|_1 \le \frac{2}{\beta} \sum_{u \in U} \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)|}{d(u)}$.

There exists a vector $c_3^+ \in \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0}^n$ with the following properties:
(3.8a) $f_3^+ \le \sum_{r \in V} c_3^+(r) \cdot \text{cost}_C(r)$.
(3.8b) $c_3^+(r) \le 2 \left( \frac{|\varphi_2^+(r)||\varphi_3^+(r)|}{d(r)} + \frac{|\varphi_2^+(r)||\varphi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} + \frac{|\varphi_2^+(r)| + |\varphi_3^+(r)|}{d(r)} \right)$, for every $r \in V$.
(3.8c) $|c_3^+|_1 \le 2 \sum_{u \in U} \left( \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)||\varphi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} + \frac{|\varphi_3^+(u)|}{d(u)} \right)$.

There exists a vector $c_2^- \in \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0}^{n}$ with the following properties:
(3.10a) $f_2^- \le \sum_{r \in V} c_2^-(r) \cdot \text{cost}_C(r)$.
(3.10b) $c_2^-(r) \le \frac{2}{1-\beta}$, for every $r \in V$.
(3.10c) $|c_2^-|_1 \le \frac{2k}{1-\beta}$.
proofs:
Proof. We can assume u, v, w are distinct since otherwise the inequality holds trivially. We assume that $d(v) \ge d(w)$ wlog.
$$
\begin{aligned}
x_{uv} + x_{uw} - x_{vw} & = \left(1 - \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)|}{M_{uv}}\right) + \left(1 - \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(w)|}{M_{uw}}\right) - \left(1 - \frac{|N_H(v) \cap N_H(w)|}{d(v)}\right) \\
& = 1 + \frac{|N_H(v) \cap N_H(w)|}{d(v)} - \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)|}{M_{uv}} - \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(w)|}{M_{uw}} \\
& \ge 1 + \frac{|N_H(v) \cap N_H(w)|}{M_{uv}} - \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)|}{M_{uv}} - \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(w)|}{M_{uw}} \\
& \ge 1 - \frac{|N_H(u) \setminus N_H(w)|}{M_{uv}} - \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(w)|}{M_{uw}} \\
& \ge 1 - \frac{|N_H(u) \setminus N_H(w)| + |N_H(u) \cap N_H(w)|}{d(u)} = 1 - \frac{|N_H(u)|}{d(u)} \ge 0.
\end{aligned}
$$
The first inequality used that $d(v) \le M_{uv}$, the second one follows from $|N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)| - |N_H(v) \cap N_H(w)| \le |(N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)) \setminus (N_H(v) \cap N_H(w))| = |(N_H(v) \cap (N_H(u) \setminus N_H(w)))| \le |N_H(u) \setminus N_H(w)|$, and the third one used $d(u) \le M_{uv}$ and $d(u) \le M_{uw}$.

Proof. Since $C(u) = C(v)$, there are at least $|N(u)\Delta N(v)|$ disagreements incident to $u$ and $v$. For every $uv \in \varphi_2^+$, we have $\text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v) \ge |N(u)\Delta N(v)| \ge \beta \cdot M_{uv}$.

Proof. For every $uv \in E_H$, we have $|N(u)\Delta N(v)| \le \beta \cdot M_{uv}$. Therefore,
$$ \min\{d(u), d(v)\} \ge |N(u) \cap N(v)| = |N(u) \cup N(v)| - |N(u)\Delta N(v)| \ge (1 - \beta) \cdot \max\{d(u), d(v)\}, $$
which gives us $(1 - \beta) \cdot d(v) \le d(u) \le \frac{1}{1-\beta} \cdot d(v)$ since $\beta \in (0,1)$.

Proof. We have $|c/\alpha|_1 \le k$ and $|c/\alpha|_\infty \le 1$. It is well known that $c/\alpha$ is a convex combination of $\{0,1\}$-vectors, each of which has at most $k$ 1's. For each $\{0,1\}$-vector $d$ in the combination, we have $\sum_{r \in V} d(r)\text{cost}_C(r) \le \text{cost}_C^k$. Taking the convex combination of these inequalities gives $\sum_{r \in V} \frac{c(r)}{\alpha}\text{cost}_C(r) \le \text{cost}_C^k$, which is equivalent to the inequality in the claim.

Proof.
$$ f_1^+ + f_1^- = \sum_{u \in U} (y_1^+(u) + y_1^-(u)) = \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_1^+ \cup \varphi_1^-} x_{uv} $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U} (|\varphi_1^+(u)| + |\varphi_1^-(u)|) \le \sum_{u \in U} \text{cost}_C(u) = \text{cost}_C^k. \quad \Box $$

Proof. We bound $f_2^+$ as follows:
$$ f_2^+ \le \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_2^+} 1 \le \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{\text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v)}{\beta \cdot M_{uv}} =: \sum_{r \in V} c_2^+(r) \cdot \text{cost}_C(r). $$
The second inequality used Lemma 3.3. Therefore, (3.7a) holds.
To show (3.7b), we bound the coefficients for $\text{cost}_C(u)$ and $\text{cost}_C(v)$ respectively. If $u \in U$, the coefficient for $\text{cost}_C(u)$ is $\sum_{uv \in \varphi_2^+(u)} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uv}} \le \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)}$; if $u \notin U$, the coefficient is 0. The coefficient for $\text{cost}_C(v)$ is $\sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_2^+(v)} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uv}} \le \frac{|\varphi_2^+(v)|}{\beta \cdot d(v)}$. Therefore, $c_2^+(r) \le \frac{2 \cdot |\varphi_2^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)}$.
To bound $|c_2^+|_1$, we can replace $\text{cost}_C(u)$ and $\text{cost}_C(v)$ with 1. Then $|c_2^+|_1 = \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{2}{\beta \cdot M_{uv}} \le \frac{2}{\beta} \sum_{u \in U} \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)|}{d(u)}$. This proves (3.7c).

Proof. Fix some $uv \in \varphi_3^+ \subseteq E_H$ with $u \neq v$. We let $\tilde{u} = \arg\max_{w \in \{u,v\}} d(w)$, and $\tilde{v}$ be the other vertex in $\{u, v\}$. Notice that $d(\tilde{u}) = M_{uv}$. Then we have
$$ x_{uv} = 1 - \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)|}{d(\tilde{u})} = \frac{d(\tilde{u}) - |N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)|}{d(\tilde{u})} = \frac{|\varphi_2^+(\tilde{u})| + |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u})| + |\varphi_1^-(\tilde{u})| - |N_H(\tilde{u}) \cap N_H(\tilde{v})|}{d(\tilde{u})} $$
$$ \le \frac{\text{cost}_C(\tilde{u}) + |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{u})| + |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{v})| + \text{cost}_C(\tilde{v})}{d(\tilde{u})} \le \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)| + |\varphi_2^+(v)| + \text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v)}{M_{uv}} \quad (5) $$
We prove the first inequality in sequence (5). Notice $N_H(\tilde{u}) \supseteq \varphi_3^+(\tilde{u})$. Therefore,
$$ |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u})| - |N_H(\tilde{u}) \cap N_H(\tilde{v})| \le |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u})| - |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u}) \cap N_H(\tilde{v})| = |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u}) \setminus N_H(\tilde{v})| \le |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{v}) \cup \varphi_1^-(\tilde{v})| $$
$$ = |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{v}) \cup \varphi_1^-(\tilde{v})| \le |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{v})| + \text{cost}_C(\tilde{v}). $$
Above, we used that $\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u}) \setminus N_H(\tilde{v}) \subseteq C(\tilde{u}) \setminus N_H(\tilde{v}) = C(\tilde{v}) \setminus N_H(\tilde{v}) \subseteq \varphi_1^+(\tilde{v}) \cup \varphi_1^-(\tilde{v})$. Also (5) holds trivially when $u=v$; this holds for every $uv \in \varphi_3^+$.
Therefore,
$$ f_3^+ = \sum_{u \in U} y_3^+(u) $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)| + |\varphi_2^+(v)| + \text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v)}{M_{uv}} $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, uw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{\text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v)}{M_{uv}} $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, uw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{\text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(w)}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{uw}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{\text{cost}_C(v) + \text{cost}_C(w)}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{vw}} $$
$$ + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{\text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v)}{M_{uv}} $$
$$ =: \sum_{r \in V} c_3^+(r) \cdot \text{cost}_C(r). $$
Again, we used Lemma 3.3 twice to prove the last inequality. Therefore, (3.8a) holds.
To prove (3.8b), we consider the coefficients for $\text{cost}_C(u)$, $\text{cost}_C(v)$ and $\text{cost}_C(w)$ respectively. For a $u \in U$, the coefficient for $\text{cost}_C(u)$ is
$$ \sum_{uv \in \varphi_3^+, uw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{uw}} + \sum_{uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} \le \frac{|\varphi_3^+(u)| \cdot |\varphi_2^+(u)|}{\beta d^2(u)} + \frac{|\varphi_3^+(u)|}{d(u)} $$
The coefficient for $\text{cost}_C(v)$ is
$$ \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_3^+(v), vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{vw}} + \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_3^+(v)} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} \le \frac{|\varphi_2^+(v)| \cdot |\varphi_3^+(v)|}{\beta d^2(v)} + \frac{|\varphi_3^+(v)|}{d(v)}. $$
The coefficient for $\text{cost}_C(w)$ is at most
$$ \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_3^+(w), uv \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uw} M_{uv}} + \sum_{vw \in \varphi_2^+, u \in U \cap \varphi_3^+(v)} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{vw}} $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_3^+(w)} \frac{d(u)}{\beta \cdot d(u) M_{uw}} + \sum_{vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{vw}} \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_3^+(v)} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} \le \frac{|\varphi_3^+(w)|}{\beta \cdot d(w)} + \frac{2 \cdot |\varphi_2^+(w)|}{\beta \cdot d(w)}. $$
Therefore, for every $r \in V$, we have $c_3^+(r) \le 2 \left( \frac{|\varphi_2^+(r)||\varphi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d^2(r)} + \frac{|\varphi_2^+(r)| + |\varphi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} + \frac{|\varphi_3^+(r)|}{d(r)} \right)$.
We then bound $|c_3^+|_1$ as follows:
$$ |c_3^+|_1 = \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, uw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{2}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{uw}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{2}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{vw}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{2}{M_{uv}} $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U} \left( \frac{2 \cdot |\varphi_2^+(u)| \cdot |\varphi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u) \cdot d(u)} + \frac{2 \cdot |\varphi_2^+(u)|}{d(u)} + \frac{2 \cdot |\varphi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} \right) $$
$$ = 2 \sum_{u \in U} \left( \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)||\varphi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d^2(u)} + \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} + \frac{|\varphi_3^+(u)|}{d(u)} \right) $$
This finishes the proof of (3.8c) and thus Lemma 3.8.

Proof. We define $c(r) = c_2^+(r) + c_3^+(r)$ for every $r \in V$. Then,
$$
\begin{aligned}
c(r) & \le 2 \frac{|\phi_2^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} + 2 \left( \frac{|\phi_2^+(r)| \cdot |\phi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d^2(r)} + \frac{|\phi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} + \frac{|\phi_3^+(r)|}{d(r)} \right) \\
& = 2 \left( \frac{|\phi_2^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} + \frac{|\phi_2^+(r)| \cdot |\phi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d^2(r)} + \frac{|\phi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} + \frac{|\phi_3^+(r)|}{d(r)} \right) \\
& \le 2 \left( \frac{|\phi_2^+(r)| + |\phi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} + \frac{|\phi_2^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} \right) \\
& \le 4 \frac{|\phi_2^+(r)| + |\phi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} \\
& \le \frac{4}{\beta},
\end{aligned}
$$
where the first inequality holds because (3.7b) and (3.8b), the second inequality holds because $|\phi_2^+(r)| \le d(r)$ and $\beta < 1$, the last inequality holds because $|\phi_2^+(r)| + |\phi_3^+(r)| \le d(r)$.

Similarly, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
|c|_1 & \le 2 \sum_{u \in U} \frac{|\phi_2^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} + 2 \sum_{u \in U} \left( \frac{|\phi_2^+(u)| \cdot |\phi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d^2(u)} + \frac{|\phi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} + \frac{|\phi_3^+(u)|}{d(u)} \right) \\
& = 2 \sum_{u \in U} \left( \frac{|\phi_2^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} + \frac{|\phi_2^+(u)| \cdot |\phi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d^2(u)} + \frac{|\phi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} + \frac{|\phi_3^+(u)|}{d(u)} \right) \\
& \le 2 \sum_{u \in U} \left( \frac{|\phi_2^+(u)| + |\phi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} + \frac{|\phi_2^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} \right) \\
& \le \frac{4}{\beta} \cdot k,
\end{aligned}
$$
where the first inequality holds because (3.7c) and (3.8c), the second inequality holds because $\beta < 1$ and for any $u \in U$ there is $|\phi_3^+(u)| \le d(u)$, the last inequality holds because for any $u \in U$ there is $|\phi_2^+(u)| + |\phi_3^+(u)| \le d(u)$.
The lemma follows from Claim 3.5.

Proof. We have
$$
f_2^- = \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_2^-} (1 - x_{uv}) = \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_2^-} \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)|}{M_{uv}} \le \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_2^-} \sum_{w \in N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)} \frac{1}{M_{uv}}.
$$
Given that $uv \in \varphi_2^-$ indicates that $C(u) \ne C(v)$, we distinguish between two cases: $C(w) = C(u)$ and $C(w) \ne C(u)$. For simplicity, in the summations below, we automatically impose the constraints $u \in U, uv \in \varphi_2^-$ and $uw, vw \in E_H$ when the vertices involved in constraints are defined. Notice that we have $d(v) \ge (1 - \beta)d(w)$ from Lemma 3.4.
$$
\sum_{u,v,w:C(w)=C(u)} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} \le \sum_{u,w:C(w)=C(u)} \frac{\text{cost}_C^+(w)}{\max(d(u), (1 - \beta)d(w))}. \quad (6)
$$
$$
\sum_{u,v,w:C(w) \ne C(u)} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} \le \sum_{u,w:C(w) \ne C(u)} \frac{d(w)}{d(u)} \le \sum_{u,w:C(w) \ne C(u)} \frac{1}{1 - \beta} \le \sum_{u \in U} \frac{\text{cost}_C^-(u)}{1 - \beta}. \quad (7)
$$
Adding (6) and (7), and using that $\text{cost}_C^+(u) \le \text{cost}_C(u)$ for every $u \in V$, we get
$$
f_2^- \le \sum_{u \in U, w \in N_H(u): C(w)=C(u)} \frac{\text{cost}_C(w)}{\max(d(u), (1 - \beta)d(w))} + \sum_{u \in U} \frac{\text{cost}_C(u)}{1 - \beta} =: \sum_{r \in V} c_2^-(r) \cdot \text{cost}_C(r).
$$
Therefore, (3.10a) holds.
To prove (3.10b), we consider the coefficients for $\text{cost}_C(u)$ and $\text{cost}_C(w)$ respectively. The coefficient for $\text{cost}_C(u)$ is $\frac{1}{1-\beta}$. The coefficient for $\text{cost}_C(w)$ is
$$
\sum_{u \in U, w \in N_H(u): C(w)=C(u)} \frac{1}{\max(d(u), (1 - \beta)d(w))} \le \sum_{u \in U, w \in N_H(u): C(w)=C(u)} \frac{1}{(1 - \beta)d(w)} \le \frac{1}{1 - \beta}.
$$
Therefore, for any $r \in V$, we have $c_2^-(r) \le \frac{2}{1-\beta}$.
By replacing $\text{cost}_C(u)$ and $\text{cost}_C(w)$ with 1, we then finished the proof of (3.10c) as follows:
\begin{align*}
|c_2^-|_1 &\le \sum_{u \in U, w \in N_H(u): C(w)=C(u)} \frac{1}{\max(d(u), (1 - \beta)d(w))} + \sum_{u \in U} \frac{1}{1 - \beta} \\
&\le \sum_{u \in U, w \in N_H(u): C(w)=C(u)} \frac{1}{d(u)} + \sum_{u \in U} \frac{1}{1 - \beta} \\
&\le \sum_{u \in U} \frac{|N_H(u)|}{d(u)} + \sum_{u \in U} \frac{1}{1 - \beta} \\
&\le \sum_{u \in U} 1 + \sum_{u \in U} \frac{1}{1 - \beta} \le \sum_{u \in U} \frac{2}{1 - \beta} = \frac{2k}{1 - \beta}.
\end{align*}
Proof. By Claim 3.5 and Lemma 3.10, we have $f_2^- \le \sum_{r \in V} c_2^-(r) \cdot \mathrm{cost}_C(r) \le \frac{2}{1-\beta} \cdot \mathrm{cost}_C^k$.
